author: .vbuterin
content: Remind me, what is the status of the various BLS elliptic curve EIPs? (for BLS-12-381, and this one https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2539 for 377)

author: .vbuterin
content: Is the plan to have the precompiles, not have them, have EVM-384 remove the need for them, something else?

author: Deleted User
content: The answer is "yes" ðŸ™‚ But more seriously, EVM-384 looks like a viable approach now, and I think it should be preferred over precompile

author: .vbuterin
content: Are there implementations of the BLS family using EVM384 yet?

author: .vbuterin
content: I saw the recent progress report talked about implementing miller loops

author: .vbuterin
content: But was wondering how far along that is, and also what the gas costs of an ecmul or a pairing would be under a realistic EVM384 rollout

author: Deleted User
content: from the architectural point of view, EVM384 is definitely a better approach than introduction of a precompile. The discussion has moved from the question "is this viable at all?" to "can we check the most expensive pieces of pairing computation" to "what about the whole implementation", which is very good progress. I do not think we should "race" the EVM384-based BLS work against the precompile work, to see which one finishes first.

author: s1na
content: Afaik miller loop is done (pending a correctness confirmation), and <@!682078300234973185> has made some progress with final exponentiation. But Paul please correct me otherwise

author: Deleted User
content: also, this is happening today:

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: link?

author: Deleted User
content: https://ethonline.org/#schedule

author: Deleted User
content: it will be on live.ethonline.org

author: pauld.9606
content: Final exponentiation is in progress. Next are subgroup checks. Then ECMUL. I have no idea about gas cost.

author: pauld.9606
content: Oh, but I don't want to discourage others from implementing these things in EVM384. I hope that someone else can do it.

author: shamatar
content: For all BLSes an answer will depend on what speed will be achieved vs Rust's 1962 implementation (slowest), then vs Go's current BLS12-381 implementation, and later on vs assembly implementation in Go or BLST library. My bet is still around 2.5-3x slowdown, so then it will be necessary to decide whether it's better to use native precompile or as was suggested before to "sponsor" such slowdown by inflating the block gas limit

author: holiman
content: We've sneak-launched Yolo-v2 now. Ethstats: https://yolov2.ethdevops.io/ (password `yolov2`) , faucet: https://faucet.yolov2.ethdevops.io/ and explorer https://explorer.yolov2.ethdevops.io/ . The genesis is here:  https://gist.github.com/holiman/b5f6e9a69cbe2c67c2b3822c15dbfc17 .

author: holiman
content: Also, <@!194432762315407360> has put in a lot of work on hive, (https://hivetests.ethdevops.io/) , and it now incorporates Trinity too (for some of the tests), plus there are new `eth` tests

author: holiman
content: Oh, and here is a yolov2 bootnode: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/master/params/bootnodes.go#L73

author: prestwich
content:
<@!273808422753796097> 
BLS status snapshot:
from a process point of view, EIP-2537 (BLS12-381) is tentatively approved for Berlin and included in the Yolo nets. EIP-2539 (BLS12-377) and EVM384 are not, although 2539 is substantially ready

The go and rust libs chosen for the 2537/2539 precompile sets are being fuzzed against eachother. I'm at ~2e7 iterations for each EIP, and I think <@!381789485777682434> has his own running 

cLabs is running an Ethereum (geth-only) testnet with 2537 and 2539 and has solidity libraries prepped for both, and a port of <@!539495253418180618>'s deposit verifier to use the 2537 lib. We've been running tests on the precompile integration without issues

author: _shemnon
content: Besu's on yolov2 - `docker run hyperledger/besu:develop --Xberlin-enabled=true --network=yolo_v2 --sync-mode=full`

author: _shemnon
content: may need to `docker pull hyperledger/besu:develop` as it's a very fresh build.

author: _shemnon
content: fast sync option `run hyperledger/besu:develop --Xberlin-enabled=true --network=yolo_v2 --fast-sync-min-peers=1 --sync-mode=fast`

author: holiman
content: Though I'd recommend clients in general to full-sync it. So clients don't miss any txs by skipping to head

author: jwasinger
content:
Hey all,

I've implemented EVM384 for Geth.  I've discovered some optimizations along the way but I feel the need to ask for input from others who may be interested and/or have more experience optimizing Go code.  Here are some instructions for building and benchmarking both Geth-evm384 and evmone-evm384: https://gist.github.com/jwasinger/41b890bc5a01b7abd4f75ae70f0641f1#file-instructions-md .  

The TLDR is that Geth-evm384 is currently 3x slower than evmone for a benchmark of our "synthetic" pairing algorithm.  The main bottleneck for evm384 is montgomery modular multiplication for which there is a 2x slowdown in Go as compared to C++.  Thus, I have good reason to believe more optimization is possible in the pure Go implementation.

In addition, based on measuring the component of overhead not due to modular arithmetic, there is a measurable slowdown in Geth's EVM vs evmone, so maybe there are speedups to be found here.

Any suggestions/input are appreciated.
